chapters.chapterTitle: The LORD's Love for Israel and Rebuke of the Priests

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Take turns reading Malachi 1 aloud together.
tips: Read slowly and clearly
Pause if something strikes you

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, summarize what this passage is about.
tips: Keep it brief
Capture the main flow

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What stood out to you the most? What's the 'best bit'?
tips: Share what personally resonated
Listen to your partner

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What is the main point or central message of this passage?
tips: Think about the author's intent
Look for the big idea

questions.title: Difficulties

tips: It's okay not to understand everything
Share honestly

chapters.chapterTitle: Warning to the Priests and Faithlessness Condemned

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Malachi 2:1-13 aloud, paying attention to the repetition of 'if you will not' in verses 1-2 and the emotional tone of weeping and groaning in verse 3.
tips: Notice the repeated phrase 'if you will not' in verses 1-2, showing the priests' refusal to obey
Pay attention to the emotional tone of weeping and groaning in verse 3, indicating the priests' distress over the altar
The term 'wife of your youth' (verse 4) is a specific reference to the covenant marriage that the priests have broken

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (the priests) does WHAT (corrupts the covenant of Levi, causes others to stumble), WHERE (post-exilic Judah), and WHY (because they have turned away from the LORD and are faithless to their wives).
tips: Include the priests' corruption of the covenant of Levi
Note the priests' weeping and groaning over the altar
Mention the breaking of the covenant with their wives (the wife of their youth)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the accusation of corrupting the covenant of Levi (verse 2), the weeping and groaning over the altar (verse 3), or the call to guard the wife of your youth (verses 4-5).
tips: The accusation of corrupting the covenant of Levi shows the depth of the priests' failure
The weeping and groaning illustrates the priests' sorrow over their own actions and the consequences
The call to guard the wife of your youth emphasizes the personal covenant that the priests broke

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Malachi trying to communicate to post-exilic Judah through this passage?
tips: Malachi is calling the priests to restore their covenant faithfulness with the LORD and with their wives
The priests' corruption of the covenant of Levi threatens the entire community because the priesthood is central to the community's worship
This passage shows that true priesthood requires both external obedience and internal integrity

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: Identify 2-3 confusing elements in this passage and clarify them.
tips: 'Covenant of Levi' refers to the special relationship God established with the Levites to serve in the temple
'Wife of your youth' symbolizes the covenant marriage that the priest entered into when he was ordained, not a current marriage
The weeping and groaning in verse 3 shows the priests' internal conflict and guilt over the altar being defiled

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply this passage to your life this week?
tips: This week, reflect on a relationship where you have been 'faithless' to a covenant (like a marriage covenant) and seek to repair it
Practice 'guarding' your spiritual covenant by spending time with God and your spouse
Ask God to help you avoid the corruption of the covenant by being faithful to Him and your spouse

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray about the warning to the priests and the call to covenant faithfulness.
tips: Thank God that He is faithful and will not abandon His people
Pray for the strength to be faithful in your marriage covenant
Ask God to help you avoid the corruption of the covenant by being faithful to Him and your spouse

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Malachi 3:1-10 aloud, paying attention to the contrast between the messenger preparing the way and the refiner's fire.
tips: Notice the phrase 'the messenger of the covenant' appears twice (v.1 and v.2) and is the one who will prepare the way
Pay attention to the repeated phrase 'he will purify the sons of Levi' (v.3) which emphasizes the need for purification
The phrase 'I do not change' (v.6) is a key declaration of God's unchanging character

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO God sends to prepare the way, WHAT God will do, WHERE this happens (the temple), and WHY (to purify His people and restore relationship).
tips: Include the messenger who prepares the way (John the Baptist) as the one who comes before Christ
Note that the purification of the sons of Levi is a sign of God's work on the priesthood
The context of post-exilic Judah: after the exile, the people have been unfaithful in tithes

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the messenger preparing the way (v.1), the refiner's fire (v.2-3), or the unchanging character of God (v.6)?
tips: The phrase 'I do not change' (v.6) is a powerful declaration that reassures the people of God's constancy
The refiner's fire metaphor (v.2-3) is vivid and shows that God's purification is both intense and necessary
The call to bring the full tithe (v.8-10) is a practical application that the people had neglected

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Malachi trying to communicate to post-exilic Judah through this passage?
tips: Malachi is warning the post-exilic Judah that their unfaithfulness in tithes and idolatry has led to a need for purification
The messenger (John the Baptist) is the one who will prepare the way for Christ, who is the refiner's fire
God's unchanging character (v.6) is the foundation for hope and restoration

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The identity of the messenger, the refiner's fire, or the concept of 'robbing God' in tithes?
tips: The 'messenger of the covenant' is a reference to John the Baptist, but in the post-exilic context, it was a new message for the people who had returned from exile
The refiner's fire is a metaphor for purification that is both destructive and transformative, not to be taken literally as a fire that burns away all
The phrase 'you are robbing me' (v.8) refers to the people not bringing the full tithe, which shows their spiritual neglect

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you bring the full tithe this week to honor God's covenant and experience His blessing?
tips: Start by calculating your tithes and contributions for the week
Bring the full tithe to the local church or to God's storehouse (as in the passage) to see the blessing
Ask God to help you in the area where you are not giving fully

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for His unchanging character and ask for the courage to bring the full tithe.
tips: Thank God that He does not change, so His promises are reliable
Pray for the courage to give the full tithe without fear
Ask God to open the windows of heaven for you with His blessing

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Malachi 4:1-6 aloud, paying attention to the contrast between the burning day of judgment and the healing of the righteous.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'the day of the LORD' (v.1, 5)
Pay attention to the phrase 'sun of righteousness' (v.2) which contrasts with the 'burning like an oven' (v.1)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO is affected, WHAT happens, WHERE it occurs, and WHY God is doing this for post-exilic Judah.
tips: Include the judgment on the arrogant and evildoers (v.1-2)
Note the restoration for those who fear God (v.2-3)
Mention the coming of Elijah (v.5) as a sign of the Messiah

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the burning day (v.1), the sun of righteousness (v.2), or Elijah's coming (v.5)?
tips: The image of the 'sun of righteousness' rising with healing in its wings is a powerful symbol of hope and restoration
The contrast between the destruction of the wicked and the thriving of the righteous is profound
Elijah's role as a forerunner of the Messiah (John the Baptist) ties this prophecy to Christ

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Malachi trying to communicate to post-exilic Judah about the coming day of the LORD?
tips: Malachi warns of God's judgment on the wicked who have not repented
He emphasizes hope for restoration for the faithful
The coming of Elijah (v.5) is a sign that the Old Testament ends with the coming of Christ

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The nature of 'the day of the LORD', the role of Elijah, or the concept of turning hearts?
tips: 'The day of the LORD' in Hebrew (yom ha-Adonai) refers to a specific day of judgment, not a generic event
Elijah is the forerunner of the Messiah (John the Baptist) who comes before the Lord (Christ), which is why he is sent now
The turning of hearts (v.6) is about restoring family and community relationships after the exile

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the theme of the sun of righteousness (healing in its wings) this week?
tips: Practice being a healer in your community by showing compassion to those who are hurting
Spend time in prayer to seek God's healing for your own life and for others
Share the hope of Christ with someone who is going through hardship

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for the hope of the sun of righteousness and ask for the strength to tread down the wicked.
tips: Thank God for the healing power of Christ that comes through the sun of righteousness
Pray for courage to be like the righteous who tread down the wicked
Ask God to send a forerunner (like Elijah) to bring repentance and restoration in your life
